author: David Balog, Schenectady Personal Finance Examiner
title: Fourth of July tax thoughts
text:
Fourth of July tax thoughts Use your key for the next article Comment Play Sen. Bernie Sanders offered a devastating indictment of Ronald Reagan in one chart showing the decline of earnings and growth for the middle class compared to the top 10 percent. on.aol.com 
On this day we celebrate American independence, based partly on the tyranny of "taxation without representation," Capital Region residents may want to consider current tax issues. Taxes rank near the top in money concerns. Photo by Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images 
What does the Declaration of Independence say about taxes? 
What does the Declaration of Independence say about taxes? Exactly one statement appears on the subject: The king had assented to Parliament's laws that "impos[e] Taxes on us without our Consent." That's it. For some reason, Americans have always thought that taxes played a bigger part in the Declaration. All it says, though, is that taxes are unacceptable if we do not impose them on ourselves. 
But taxes have always concerned Americans. Here are some thoughts: 75% of Americans overpay their taxes. In other words, they get a tax refund, averaging $3,000 per family. In essence, they are giving a free loan to the government. That's money better spent investing in their futures. They can get that money in their paychecks by increasing their exemptions on the W4 form. Pay an IRA, not the IRS. Lotto is a regressive tax. Those least able to afford this tax pay the most. Lotto is not a retirement plan. Since the 1980s and the Reagan Revolution (followed by the G.W. Bush tax cuts) the wealthiest Americans are paying the lowest rates of taxes since the introduction of the Income Tax. In the job-creating 1950s and 60s, the average taxable income rate for wealthy Americans ranged in area of 90%. Back in the 1950s, when the top marginal tax rate was more than 90 percent, real annual growth averaged more than 4 percent. During the last eight years, when the top marginal rate was just 35 percent, real growth was less than half that. 
The middle class needs to better understand taxes (even a little bit) and get tax relief. Trickle down economics has not worked. Suggested Links
